awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Exploration of Positively Selected Regions of the Human Genome Shaping Pelvis and Scapula Evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Bones differ in shape and size throughout an animal's body and between animal species, but the underlying genetic mechanisms that result in different looking bones are not well understood. This doctoral dissertation project will investigate DNA "instruction manuals," particularly the "switches" that turn gene expression on or off during development, that result in shape differences in hip and shoulder bones of humans and chimpanzees. The project will advance knowledge about hip and shoulder developmental genetics in the context of modern human skeletal evolution. The project will support graduate research and training; 1-2 undergraduates also will have the opportunity to gain lab experience. The co-PI will use her work in a Life Science Outreach program at Harvard University as an opportunity to discuss this research and other facets of human evolution and genetics with New England high school biology teachers and students, ideally recruiting interested students to visit the lab and serve as summer researchers. The PI and co-PI's close ties with the Harvard Museum of Natural History will allow for the development of public exhibits and events that showcase bone biology, genetics, and human evolution.

Researchers have discussed a number of evolutionary pressures, primarily related to the adoption of bipedalism, that are likely to have acted on pelvis and scapula morphology during hominin evolution. However, little is known about underlying genomic mechanisms that resulted in the observed changes in the shape and structure of these bones. This project will investigate portions of the genome that were previously identified as having potential activity and regulatory functions during embryonic pelvis and scapula development. The genomic sequences being specifically investigated overlap with regions of DNA that show signs of having been under positive selection in the human lineage. For each of these regulatory sequences, the researchers will test whether the human and chimpanzee versions of the sequence control gene activity, and whether there are differences in gene activity between the two species. This work will help to identify sequences likely to have been under selection during human evolution to produce the modern human pelvis and scapula.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Human bipedalism is a hallmark trait that separates humans (and immediate human ancestors) from other non-human primates such as chimpanzees and gorillas (African apes). The origins of bipedalism revolved around morphological changes to the hindlimb, most notably the pelvis, knee, and foot. One of the most dramatically reorganized structures in the hindlimb is the pelvis, whereby the human ilium (upper part of the pelvis) has become short, broad, and is wrapped around the body compared to those of African apes; anatomical changes that changed the structure and function of muscles that move the leg during human bipedal walking and running. To date we understand little about how the human pelvis develops embryonically and why it looks different from those of African apes.

 

We approached this task using a series of different computational and functional analyses in the laboratory.  We first used functional genomics methods to identify the genes and regulatory sequences involved in mouse pelvis development, the best studied mammalian system to date. We intersected the thousands of regulatory regions we uncovered for each of the different parts of the mouse pelvis (ilium, pubis, ischium, acetabulum) with data we independently acquired on human pelvis development (i.e., outside these proposed/funded studied). We found that there were regulatory sequences and genes shared between humans and mice, and those unique to each species. We next took the regulatory sequences identified for the ilium (the unique structure that evolved in humans compared to chimpanzees) and intersected them with regions of the genome known to have evolved at a rapid evolutionary pace, indicative of the effects of ancient natural selection. These regions are called human accelerated regions or HARs. We found that 23 regions uniquely involved in human pelvic ilium development overlapped with HARs.

 

However, at this stage of the project we did not know what these 23 regions (HARs/ilium regulatory sequences) do in terms of their effects on human genes and pelvis development. We therefore set up a system called a functional reporter assay that allowed us to test each region for its effects on a gene’s expression. In this context, we tested for each sequence overlapping a HAR, whether the human sequence version changes the expression of the reporter gene compared to the corresponding chimpanzee sequence version. We tested both versions of each region simultaneously in human cell lines involved in skeletal development. We discovered that of the 23 regions, 10 act as regulatory regions in these skeletal cell lines and that 7 show differences in activities between human and chimpanzee version of each sequence. These 7 regions are likely important drivers of human pelvic ilium shape changes since all humans possess these sequences overlapping HARs compared to chimpanzees. These 7 regions were also nearby key genes involved in skeletal development in humans and mice.

 

In the context of this investigation, our studies provided direct training for a female STEM scientist in human biology and computational biology. They also fostered the training of undergraduates in the tools of molecular biology and computational biology. Aspects of these studies were included in a recent publication from the lab on the development of the human pelvis in the journal Science Advances. The functional reporter assays described above are currently being incorporated into a large publication for submission to a refereed journal, and the data will be used by skeletal biologists, geneticists, and evolutionary anthropologists to help understand how DNA sequences aid in human adaptation. These data will also be incorporated into several museum exhibits to foster the understanding of human evolution, and how DNA sequences control human traits, including those involved in our ability to walk upright.
